abstract_summ: Here we are presenting a case of arterial thrombosis in a patient with COVID-19 and a systematic review on coagulopathy associated with COVID-19.We report a case of a 75-year-old woman diagnosed with severe coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) complicated by acute cerebral infarction.Risk stratification for deep vein thrombosis and peripheral arterial disease are of vital importance for the prognosis of COVID-19.We describe three patients with COVID-19 who presented with an acute vascular event rather than typical respiratory symptoms.Due to the hypercoagulable state, blood stasis and endothelial injury, severe patients with COVID-19 are at high risk for thrombosis.Our cases and discussion highlight the thrombotic complications caused by COVID-19, management of these patients, and explores the role of anticoagulation in patients diagnosed with COVID-19.Severe COVID-19 may predispose to both venous and arterial thrombosis.This letter aimed to draw attention to the role of pulmonary thromboembolism as a potential and possible cause of clinical deterioration in covid-19 patients.• In the occurrence of new-onset neurological symptoms in COVID-19 patients, we should suspect an acute ischemic stroke and not assume that it is secondary to the respiratory syndrome (hypoxia).
